intro: Brachistus haughtii, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to the arid regions of the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, which includes daisies and sunflowers, and is characterized by its composite flower heads. The plant typically grows from 10 to 30 centimeters tall, with hairy stems and small, yellow flowers that bloom in spring. Its leaves are usually lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, helping to reduce water loss in hot, dry environments. Brachistus haughtii is adapted to survive in poor soils and can thrive with minimal water, making it a resilient species in desert ecosystems.
